The history of the Egyptian pyramids dates back to around 2700 BCE during the Old Kingdom period of ancient Egypt. These monumental structures were built as tombs for the pharaohs, who were considered divine rulers and believed to continue their rule in the afterlife.

The first pyramid, known as the Step Pyramid, was constructed at Saqqara for Pharaoh Djoser by his architect Imhotep. It was a revolutionary design, consisting of six stacked mastabas (rectangular structures with sloping sides) and reaching a height of around 6 steps. This pyramid marked the transition from the earlier royal tombs, which were primarily underground structures called mastabas.

The true pyramids, with smooth sides and a pointed top, began with the reign of Pharaoh Sneferu. He built three pyramids: the Meidum Pyramid, the Bent Pyramid, and the Red Pyramid. The Meidum Pyramid started as a step pyramid but was later converted into a true pyramid. The Bent Pyramid, located in Dahshur, has a unique design with a change in angle halfway up, giving it a bent appearance. The Red Pyramid, also in Dahshur, is the first successful attempt at constructing a true pyramid.

The most famous pyramids were built during the Fourth Dynasty, including the Great Pyramid of Giza. Pharaoh Khufu, also known as Cheops, constructed the Great Pyramid, which is the largest and oldest of the three pyramids at Giza. It is estimated to have taken around 20 years to complete and was originally covered in smooth limestone casing stones. The pyramids of Khafre and Menkaure, built by Khufu's successors, are also located at Giza.

The construction of pyramids required immense manpower and resources. The pharaohs employed skilled architects, engineers, and laborers who worked year-round. The stones used for the pyramids were quarried from nearby areas and transported to the construction site using sledges and ramps. The precise techniques used to align the pyramids with the cardinal directions and the mathematical precision of their construction remain a subject of fascination and study.

After the Old Kingdom, pyramid construction declined, and subsequent pharaohs opted for hidden tombs in the Valley of the Kings. The pyramids were looted over time, and their outer casing stones were often removed for other construction projects. However, the pyramids still stand as iconic symbols of ancient Egypt's grandeur and continue to captivate people from around the world.
